Description: Model of equipment for Opening of Mouth Ceremony: five vessels (calcite and limestone), a small knife blade and a 'peseshkef' implement (schist and limestone) set into depressions of limestone tablet.
Curator's comments: This set of miniature models of real implements dates to the Old Kingdom. At that time it would appear that the Opening of the Mouth ritual was different from and simpler than its later developed form. The function of the 'peseshkef' implement has been debated. It may have supported the jaw of the mummy, or else might have played a part in the process of childbirth and thus have been used symbolically to bring about rebirth after death. Bibliography: J. H. Taylor, ‘Death and the afterlife in ancient Egypt’ (London, 2001), p. 191 (fig. 134); W. Seipel, 'Ägypten' Vol. 1 (Linz, 1989), p.85 [52a-h]; J.H. Taylor and N.C. Strudwick, Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt. Treasures from The British Museum, Santa Ana and London 2005, pp. 156-7, pl. on p. 156. D. Antoine and M. Vandenbeusch, Egyptian mummies. Exploring ancient lives, Sydney 2016, p. 42.
Bibliographic references: Taylor & Strudwick 2005 / Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt (p.156-157)
